reviewText:
Orcs Must Die! 2 is the follow up to Orcs Must Die 1, and is a third person tower defence game, developed by Robot Entertainment.  The game was released on PC July 2012.

The main difference with Orcs Must Die 2 is the addition of co-op gameplay. Everything else is virtually the same. You play either as a War Mage or sorceress in the story mode. You have to defend at one or more rifts which open at the start of the level. Each level has a varying amount of waves of enemies continuously spawning in order to reach said rift. Your aim is to stop them by building traps whilst also using your own character to kill them as well. Before each level you choose your load out of traps that you want to use. You start out by only being able to take 4 or 5, but work your way up to being able to take 10 traps on a stage with you.  Before jumping into each level too, you can upgrade your traps to do more damage, have a lower cool down time, or some other ability such as slowing the enemy if they are hit by it for example.  You'll notice from the very beginning that there are a few traps that you'll always want to take with you, such as the slowing trap - but included in your loadout, is your characters weapon, so you have to choose carefully.

You are given an infinite amount of time to build your traps at the start of each level, and you are also given a healthy amount of time between waves to allow you to build more. You are granted extra coins after each wave, and for killing enemies, and you use these coins to purchase more traps. Whilst you can also place traps when enemies are spawning, this isn't always a good idea as your main focus should be on killing enemies then.  A large portion of this game is actually you spamming your left mouse button using your main weapon, whilst you aren't able to destroy everything with this weapon; it is more used as filler for your time as most of the damage will come from the traps.  There is a huge variety of traps as well, and you probably won't even use them all even by the end of the game, leaving you plenty of chances to experiment.

The graphics in Orcs Must Die 2 are really nice. They are in the cartoon style that many of us really enjoy, but they aren't so childish that they can't portray the maturity of the title. There are some really nice special effects, such as the lava and ice traps, they all look marvellous. Everything is perfectly animated too, whilst a lot of the enemies are copy/pasted, that is to be expected from a game of this type.

Orcs Must Die 2 has a very catchy sound track too; the song is played constantly and it will be driven into your head and you'll be whistling it without realising it. Other than the soundtrack, the rest of the game's audio is brilliant too. The game is narrated in the cut scenes by the male character; it would have been nice to get voice acting on the female though.

This game has varying levels of difficulty, the regular easy, medium and hard mode. You only unlock hard mode after you have beaten the game. There is one other form of difficulty, and that is endless mode. This will pit you against an endless stream of enemies, meaning you have to constantly upgrade your traps and the enemies will not stop until they either kill you or destroy your rift. This mode will really test your metal but is extremely fun to play in. Most players should really be playing this game on the Medium skill level, the easy mode is too easy and will not really offer any challenge to any tower defence veteran.

All of the levels in Orcs Must Die 2 are so well designed; I cannot find any faults with them at all. The early stages of the game are a tutorial stage really, allowing you to test out your traps to work out how they are best used, so the levels are pretty simple, but once you reach the end levels, you'll really be putting your trap building skills to the test, as you have to defend multiple rifts from multiple entry points of enemies. Some of the bigger levels offer a bit of support in getting around quickly in the form of teleporters, these will teleport you to the other side of the map once stepping in them.

I have been playing Orcs Must Die 2 for almost thirty hours, this is because there is absolutely tons of content in this game, not only is the single player story mode eight hours of gameplay, you also have the added replay ability of playing the story again as the other hero (with different skills and abilities), and then you also can replay the whole game again on co-op which adds a whole another level of content as the enemies are all scaled up to match you and your friend - and finally, we have the endless mode, this is the part of the game that I have spent the majority of my time and I am absolutely hooked on it. As you play the story mode, once you reach the final waves of a level, you'll often feel like you wish you could carry on and see how far you get, you can do that in endless mode; you just keep building traps, and facing more and more enemies as they just keep coming. This mode alone has given me about fifteen hours of gameplay.

Orcs Must Die 2 can be played on all resolutions. I played on 4k with everything on max settings and was able to get 60 FPS constantly. I did however have a few crashes, this mainly happened when you minimize the game too many times, and it gives you a message something regarding DirectX. Although this was annoying, I only had it when minimizing and not whilst in the midst of gameplay. The game can be played with a controller, but as it has elements of aiming with a crosshairs, the game is highly recommended to be played with a keyboard/mouse - it just works so much better on them.

This game is an absolute must play for any tower defence fan, if you had any sort of enjoyment out of the first, you'll get more of the same out of this, and the added edition of co-op makes it even more appealing to a wider audience. Not to mention the hours and hours of content on offer in this game. The regular price tag of Â£10, 99 is fairly marked and should be considered a must play for me.

6) This is a must play

reviewText:
If you aren't going to play this game Co-Op with a friend, don't bother with this game. Orcs Must Die! was a great game and could be played alone. When you play Orcs Must Die! 2 alone, you notice something almost immediately; the design of the new levels is clearly built for Co-Op action with a friend. The early levels are easy regardless, and there are some fun new mechanics that you can play with (funneling the orcs along minecart paths) which is a nice change from the first game, where you just look for the best place to place your Swinging Maces. Sadly, once you get about midway through the game some of the interesting levels seem to have already passed. Most of the time through barricades or planning you could get 3 or 4 doors worth of orcs to run through one setup of traps, which is about what was needed to clear the levels on War Mage difficulty. Sadly, about midway through OMD!2, it seems someone decided to make a whole pile of symmetrical levels in which there is no common area to filter all of the orcs through. Fair enough, it must still be possible to do it alone right?

If you've played the first game, you can picture what I am going to describe now: Imagine a 6 square wide path. There is only a buildable wall on one side. The other side of the path has a few blocks of lava, which cannot be used because if you try to throw them into it they just fly clear of the lava river onto the symmetrical path on the other side (past the point where your traps would be). There is a small section with a ceiling on which to build ceiling traps but Swinging Mace now basically does no damage and just throws the orcs away from your other traps. If you spend all of your money on one side of the level, you might get lucky with a setup that can stop the first 2 waves using all of the right traps in the limited possible building areas, but what do you do on the other side? Fight the whole waves yourself with no trap assistance? Goodluck, it works for a few levels and then you just get completely overwhelmed, You never end up with enough money to defend both sides, and you need to spend what you get to build up your untrapped side, and the original side that you built to start is leaking orcs (a lot of them) every level.

There are a few levels like this in a row probably about 75% of the way through the game. You clearly need 2 players, so each can play their own separate game on their own side of the level. How is that fun?

The first game was great. This one, not so much. I've had enough.

reviewText:
ORC MUST DIE! 2 A Review

INTROOrc Must Die! 2 developed and published by Robot Entertainment[www.robotentertainment.com] is a continuation for the original Orc Must Die which includes the original cast but is now expanded with more maps, more items/weapons, and above all MORE ORCS to kill.

Anyways this is a tower defense game with the difference is that you are on the ground with weapons to fight off the orcs as well so its a hybrid of third person tower defense action game. A mouthful I know but it actually works! And its fun with friends as well since it has coop now!

So lets get this review typing.

GameplayMake Character>Choose Map>Choose Difficulty>Choose Loadout>KIll Orcs>Win [or not]>Buy Upgrades>Repeat

Orc Must Die 2 happens to feature a narrative like the first one in the form of you getting more story context by finishing a level and unlocking the next one with a cutscene playing at certain point. Also in game dialogue between the two character serves as a story context.

Anyways, first you choose to either play as the male Warmage with more HP but less mana or the female Sorceress with more mana but less HP. Loadouts also differs slightly between the two with the Warmage having access to melee weapons along with shotgun while the Sorceress is more spell based with more staff and so on but the towers are mostly shared.

Once thats over you can then proceed to choose your map, difficulty and play either solo or coop. Maps for the main campaign are unlocked by clearing the ones before it and clearing it also unlock more tower type and more loadout slots.

Once in game you can then choose between a lot of weapons and towers provided you have unlocked them already. Initially you only have 3 slots but more are given as you clear map and the slots are shared between accesories. weapons, guardians, and traps so its prudent to choose wisely for the enemy type you will be facing which is indicated on the loadout screen.

You have a limited funds at start to build your first few traps with more funds gained from killing Orcs, collecting coins, and achieving combos by killing several orcs at once or quickly. Traps ranges from the typical spike and arrow trap to the much cooler acid and ice traps but there are lot more kind with some serving a more utilitarian functions.

Orcs spawn from predefine points on the map and they will charge straight at the limited life teleporter that you must defend. The path they take can be influence by putting traps that block their path although if the map have several brancing paths or there are two teleporter at once they will split up. Initially only 1 spawn point will be active but by the 4th wave usually all are actively pouring in. There are a lot of types of orcs from the typical grunt all the way to elemental monster that can split up to 3 times. Also flying enemies are also present with some weapons and traps can not be use against them and they will ignore all blockade that you made.

Once you placed the traps and start the round it will continue until all orcs are dead which will give you a  10 second breather to sell/build more towers but while you can build during an attack you can only sell during these grace period in between rounds. At the middle point and right before the final round the game will give you an indefinite break until you trigger the wave yourself but the timer that affects your ranking still runs so its imperative to build/sell/break quickly and resume.

Alright provided you won all the round you will then win the game and be presented with  a stat screen showing how well you did then everything is tally up and Skulls which are currencies are then dole out to you to spend. The main factor I see that affects is how fast you finish a map, letting no orc get to the teleporter, and not dying.

Skulls can be use at the shops to unlock more weapons or upgrade an existing ones to be better. Same goes for traps and guardians and the good thing is that you can reset your build at any time you want at no cost whatsoever and its actually quite common to jump into a new map only to restart it because the build you have are not up to the task.

Then rinse and repeat until you beat every single one of your friend's score.

GraphicsOrc Must Die 2 uses a cartoony style approach to represent their game and it works well with the goofyness that the orc has [along with the idiocy of the Warmage]. Funnily enough if you turn on gib mode to high they will literally explode into chunks of meat when they die.

SoundI suppose the sound are acceptable for all the weapon/spells and trap effect although the voice acting is pretty stellar for the orcs, guardians, and player character. A shame for hard hearing people though as explain below.

Option Menu and ControlRebindable keys check, resolution anti-alias vsync windowed mode check although graphics setting are limited to high and low with no advance option. All the usual audio stuff check along with some gameplay options. No disability options though.

Runs smoothly and if you ever need this for some reason it runs at  60 fps.

So what is the issue? The dialogue options is only for the cutscene not for when the character talks in-game or quip something when they perform an action and such. That means you can barely hear it if you have hearing isssue.

As for controls I used the keyboard and it is solid, no issues there.

ConclusionOrc Must Die! 2 is a solid action tower defense game that does a humorous spin on the classic formula, abundant of maps, nice enemy selection, and a great amount of traps and weapons are sure to entertain you. It gets even better when you play coop. Overall an excellent game in its category. A F***KING SHAME THE SEQUEL IS A MOBA.

Scoring Methology:
-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

Verdict: S-Rank - Awarded for giving out many fun time in its category.

reviewText:
Overview
Orcs Must Die! 2 is a tower defense game in which you must construct traps to defeat an ever-increasing wave of orcs and their minions. The game can be played in single player or two person co-op. For those familiar with the formula, the game follows the standard idea of building defenses, weaving the path that the enemy must follow and defeat them before they reach the exit. The game itself is set in a 3rd person view, allowing the player to control one of two characters that you may use to fight along-side your traps. During setup, the player may choose from a variety of traps: spike traps, arrow traps, teleporters, acid traps, barricades, guardians (AI), character weapons and trinkets for passive and active buffs. There is a healthy amount of customization what you can bring, making level design easily tailored to your play style and choice.

During the matches, the goal is simple: Do not let the orcs, or their minions, past the rift (exit). Each level has a set amount of waves, enemy types and number of rift points (essentially lives) that can be expended before you lose the round. Depending on your success, the player(s) can earn bonus points in the form of skulls. These skulls can be used to upgrade your weapons, trinkets and most importantly, your traps, adding active and passive abilities and increased damage.

The game has several different game modes, including story mode, several smaller DLC levels, a weekly custom mode and an Endless Mode, which, as you'd have guessed, goes until you lose or quit the level. Aside from different game modes, Orcs Must Die! 2 has three difficulties: Apprentice (Easy), War Mage (Normal) and Nightmare (Hard). As someone who has played very few tower defense games, War Mage is a nice middle ground for those just learning the game or the genre.

The game will probably provide anywhere from 20-30 hours of continuous gameplay, more so if you explore the different modes and difficulties that it has to offer. Orcs Must Die! 2 is enjoyable, yet challenging. It blends old features with new content very well. if you're a fan of tower defense games, then I think you'll enjoy Orcs Must Die! 2.

Pros
Interesting enemy types and level design.
Character artwork and overall visual effects are very well done.
The customization of your arsenal is fleshed out and provides a lot of variety in your build.
Voice acting - While there is minimal, what is there is cute. I enjoyed the back and forth between the characters.
Replayability - With the weekly challenge and the Endless Mode, the game offers a nice bit of replayability for fun, or to challenge yourself after you've finished the story.
No broken achievements - They are all obtainable.
Co-Op - the game shines if you have a partner to play with.
Cons
Story - It's there, sort of, but it isn't really fleshed out aside from a bit of dialogue and a cutscene here and there.
Orc Mages - Their ranged attack can, at times, feel a little cheap (they home in on your character...a lot...)

Overall, Orcs Must Die! 2 is downright fun. It's a challenge without being irritating and a ton of fun if you're able to play co-op. It's a great installment to the series and feels improved in every fashion. Check it out. I completely recommend it!

reviewText:
Orcs Must Die 2 continues right where 1 left off. The much-awaited multiplayer experience is here, but this review will be from a single-player standpoint.

To start with, you get to pick between the Warmage and the Sorceress. Both have their strengths and weaknesses, but the Warmage simply feels easier to play with due to his superior health, superior tar trap, and arguably superior weapon. The Sorceress is better for charming single, large targets though, and her acid trap does more damage than the Warmage's Arrow Trap.

Gameplay is more or less the same. If you played OMD1, this will all be familiar. The Elementalist girls are gone, which is a shame. This change means that you have less options to adjust to your enemies in the middle of a level. Fortunately any upgrades you purchased prior to battle can be reset at no cost. Autoballistae are now considered guardians, which means you can no longer spam them. I was sad about that as well.

Amazingly they made the Gnolls more irritating. They seem to have more HP, run faster (both probably untrue, but it feels like it), and can now slow you upon hitting you, making escape impossible. A whole pack of them, especially in Endless mode (see below), will ruin your day.

I'm rather disappointed that the campaign is so short. The first game took maybe 15-20 hours to complete, and had a good progression. OMD2 instead took me a mere 10 hours on normal difficulty. Granted, I already knew the basics of the game, but this was far shorter than I expected. DLC's extend the game's length a bit, but they contain no story segments, and thus you are basically playing for skulls (the game's peristent currency) and variety. Note that you'll have to play through Campaign again with another character if you want stuff unlocked on both characters.

Endless mode is interesting. Waves come indefinitely and keep getting tougher until you can no longer handle it, much like Survival mode in other types of games. This mode by far is the biggest time-sink, though you are rewarded with plenty of skulls to compensate.

If you like the first game and want a way to play it with friends, then OMD2 is the way to go. Overall it's an acceptable game. I still recommend the first game though.

reviewText:
Personal rating: 9/10
DLC: Adds a lot to the game without putting any game breaking stuff. Complete Pack is very worth it.

About Orcs Must Die! 2:It is a fast paced, tower defense game which requires you to be crafty and resourceful from the beginning until the end. But unlike most common defense tower games you actively participate in the battle, you are main defense, your towers, or rather traps, will hinder, soften or thin out the horde, but you'll still have a lot of heavy lifting to do by yourself.

About the gameplayOrcs Must Die! 2 is more refined than its predecessor, it fixes little tweaks that were very annoying in the first game and balances weapons that back then felt a little too powerful and buffs weapons that were otherwise almost useless or felt too weak to be of proper use.

There's a lot of variation in your towers, or rather, traps. You can out them on the ground, walls and ceiling and some traps requires certain strategies to work well. Obviously there are traps that works better with others, but nothing is truly impossible to combine, you create your own set of traps to watch enemies get brutally pierced/crushed/burnt/frozen/stripped to the bones.

The game makes sure to bring new foes and tricks to ensure that you will always try something new, something you hadn't thought before or to show that your old tactics will eventually stop working.

Improvements over the first gameOrcs Must Die! 2 fixes a lot of little things that were annoying in the first game some are noticeable such as clunky physics with Wind Belt, other are more subtle like not being able to place Boom Barrels too close to enemies and removing fall damage which was completely needless.

Another big change was the improvements over control customization and options overall which was seriously lacking in the first Orcs Must Die!

All in all once you play the first game you'll realize how the differences can affect in your game style.

How difficulty is it?Orcs Must Die! 2 can be difficult, a bit overwhelming at first, but you will rarely feel that the game was unfair, that it did something ridiculous that you couldn't counter before it happened. It is a rewarding experience and you will feel great whenever you pull a maximum rank victory, especially on Nightmare (I'll talk about it in a moment).

The game was tailored for co-op action and after the first stage you'll be facing two enemy spawn points to defend and it can feel unfair, especially in the beginning when you barely have anything to deal with them, it can be difficult but it's still manageable.

While not something I truly appreciate, you'll have to go back to certain levels when you have better equipment to ace it (5 skull). Sure, you can start playing from the get go with a friend, but damn if it doesn't make you feel like a complete pro player when you get that maximum rank victory in a difficult map all by yourself.

Nightmare?The Nightmare difficulty, unlocked by finishing the game once, is far from being a numerical difficulty where the game merely ups enemies health or their numbers (something that plagues the games ever since they were made), it ramps up the difficulty to above the roof showing even tougher enemies and giving you puny three seconds to sell traps/units. You'll be forced to rethink your strategies and sometimes change to things you never ever thought before.

Bring friend to kill orcs. Have twice as fun.The co-op is just plain fun. Even more enemies to kill with a friend is never enough and being able to share strategies and putting up your traps into synergy is pure glee. If you don't have friends to play with you can always ask for others in the multiplayer groups.

Orcs Must Die, sure, but there are few problems...There are two complaints about this great game I have: grinding and character selection.
Grinding is bad enough (maximizing traps, accessories and weapons is expensive), but having to do twice because you have to create two separate game files for each character is just increasing the longevity of the game in a bad way, especially since it can take a while to notice the differences between both characters aside from the obvious.

Changing characters requires you to return to the main menu screen, which wouldn't be such a hassle if you didn't have to leave the Party you made for multiplayer which can be very annoying.

There's also the fact Orcs Must Die! 2 is MUCH shorter than it's predecessor. While the first game has whooping 24 maps in the main campaign, the second game has only 15. Of course with the Classic levels DLC (earned by having the first game) the second game is longer, but I'm was never a big fan of having to rely on DLC to have a game with good length.

Final commentariesOrcs Must Die! 2 is an excellent game. It has tons of replay value and is balanced decently for both co-op and solo play. It does feel like it's an Orcs Must Die! 1 v2.0" but with so many new traps

Yet another game somehow I found myself addicted to.

It started off simple - got this as a gift from a friend, was bored didn't have anything else to play. Okay why not - she got me the game may as well try it. I am extremely glad I did because this simple tower defense idea became Orcs Must Die.

The gameplay is simple, a tower defense sort of idea. Basically there isn't a shortage of what to choose from when it comes to beating up the orcs. Defenses and even weapons can be upgraded with the amount of skulls you collect per level. There is a relatively large amount of different towers and abilities in the game when compared to many other games in the tower defense genre. You have plenty of options and can have fun experimenting with different strategies. The level designs also vary enough that they call for different approaches to beat them, so you will have to try out different tactics in order to succeed. And there is a fair amount of different enemies which keeps things fresh as you progress through the game.

There is also a scoring system and leaderboards to add replay value.

Orcs Must Die! 2 is a step forward from the already amazing first game.  All the good aspects return, with some new ideas sprinkled in. There are many more traps and abilities, and a more extensive upgrade system.  There are many new enemies. Also the addition of cooperative mode makes the experience exponentially more fun if you have a friend to play with.

I would say practically everyone should enjoy the Orcs Must Die! games.  Many hours of fun to be had with the games in this series, I recommend playing both.

reviewText:
This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend Orcs Must Die! 2 then skip to Results and read from there.

Robot Entertainment makes a fantastic addition to their brilliant tower defense game. Orcs Must Die! 2 adds new elements of gameplay to the tower defense genre by mixing FPS, TD, and RPG games.

Story:
The War Mage has seals the final rift taking magic away from the world, but forever protecting it from the orcs continually onslaught. The world begins to crumble as magic no longer influences the weather i, sickness, and food. People are realizing the harsh world that they inhabit as magic is taken away. The Sorceress no longer has the ability to control the hordes of orcs, as her magic is gone and she has not long to live before they finally dispose of her. But The Master with his last fleeting breath hopes to give the kingdom one last chance opens a rift bringing back The Sorceress. The Master hopes The Sorceress will learn from her mistake and join The War Mage to restore the Order and bring back magic to the world again.

Campaign:
Orc Must Die! 2 offers two acts, the first consist of seven levels and the second of eight. They start out with each level only being a few waves, and then gradually increasing till you get to the last level which is about twelve waves. Similar to the original you cannot save half way into a level, meaning you need to make sure you have the time available to beat a level before you start it. The game also offers Endless Mode, which includes a variety of levels, some seen in the campaign and others that are unique. Endless mode allows you to obtain skulls (the currency used to buy upgrades) while at the same time getting to practice strategies. The campaign is played similar to the first one where you must place towers to defend rifts from being attacked, but incorporates more RPG elements. If you own Orcs Must Die! the original, you will also be given ten special levels in classic mode. Classic mode essentially is the best parts of the original campaign that can be played co-op and with the new features. This also allows you to earn more skulls and develop your character.

Gameplay:
Orcs Must Die! 2 allows you to play as one of two characters: The Sorceress and The War Mage. The War Mage has higher health while The Sorceress offers more mana. As such one is focused more around using melee and non-magic weapons and the other is based more on magic and spell-casting. This allows you to change how you will play right from the start of the campaign. Unlike Orcs Must Die! you can no longer upgrade your character with coins through the weavers. Instead you buy trinkets using skulls that offer your character passive abilities, upgrade your towers with skulls and unlock unique abilities for the towers, and upgrade weapons with skulls. Each level allows you to get five skulls, plus any additional bonus skulls you pick up as result of enemy drops. This gameplay is focused much more on RPG style gameplay and beating the campaign on War Mage with 5 skulls for every level is near impossible if you donât grind yourself up in Endless Mode.

Multiplayer:
Orcs Must Die! 2 offers multiplayer, finally you can play co-op as one player is The Sorceress and the other is The War Mage. I personally never played multiplayer, but its nearly self-explanatory that this adds all new elements to the game. A lot of the levels seem as though they are designed for two players, requiring you to essentially run from one side of the map to the other during waves. Adding multiplayer takes Orcs Must Die! and combines it with Sanctum taking the best from both worlds.

Fire and Water:
The first DLC pack for Orcs Must Die! 2. The levels include new levels (Traffic Jammed, Double Decker, and The West Wing), new enemies (Fire and Water Lords), and new traps (Web Spinner, Dart Spitters, and Floor Portal). Double Decker is one of my favorite levels; it is a two pathed level where you get to use minecarts to stop your foes. The new enemies Fire and Water Lords offer all new challenges, if you donât kill them quick enough they evolve. They can evolve two times starting at Firelings and becoming Fire Lords. The Fire Lords are similar to Ogres and have a lot of health while the Firelings are like Orcs. I personally liked the Dart Spitters came in handy on levels where I wanted to concentrate traps, but ran out of space.

Family Ties:
This DLC further expands Orc Must Die! 2 offering loads of new content: three new levels, two new weapons, a new trinket, and even some new enemies. The levels include: Rush Hour, Breakneck Triad, and Triple Threat. The new levels are really well designed and can be played easily solo or with a group. One of the new weapons, Stone Staff, was actually my favorite weapon as it allows you to essentially freeze enemies then do increased damage to them. The Hobgoblin Healer is a very good addition and requires you to focus your strategy differently as they can cause a simple attach to be very difficult. The Ball and Chain is essentially just a stronger Ogre. Overall this is a great addition to the game, and the new weapon in my opinion is the best in the game.

Are We There Yeti?:
This is another exciting DLC pack offered with Orcs Must Die! 2. The pack includes three levels: Yeti Den, The Hive, and Chilled Cavern. These levels introduce new characters (Yeti and Goblin Sapper) and offer a new weapon/trap/trinket. In my opinion these new levels are the hardest ones Iâve played in the Orcs Must Dies series, specifically âYeti Denâ. I played the levels on War Mage and beat them solo, but definitely could not do that on Nightmare. The levels are set up to be played with multiple people and this pack would probably be a lot more entertaining on multiplayer.

Results:
Orcs Must Die! 2 is a fantastic game that combines RPG, FPS, and TD into one single game. With co-op play you can mess around with your friends and play the maps to a whole new level. Orcs Must Die! 2 also integrate Orcs Must Die! campaign into the game (if you own the latter) allowing you to play the original levels with the new elements of the Orcs Must Die! 2. There are way more weapons to mess around with, loads more spells, trinkets, and special tower upgrades making Orcs Must Die! 2 a great addition to the first game. With loads of DLC to add to it this game is a must buy. If you are unsure or maybe just frugal, such as myself, then wait till the complete pack is on sale and grab that. As you will want to buy the DLC once you really get into the game.

Pros:
+A campaign consisting of 15 new levels
+Addition of endless mode that lets you go nuts.
+Loads of new baddies (including the Orc Mages and Shaman from Orcs Must Die! DLC)
+Co-Op play so you can mess around with a friend and have a great new experience
+Incorporating RPG elements to the game
+Three DLC packs
+If you own the original you get Classic mode which includes ten levels from Orcs Must Die!
+Loads of new spells (including spells from Orcs Must Die! DLC)
+Loads of new towers (offering different play strategies)
+Trinkets (which give you passive and active abilities)
+Character customization with new costumes.
+The story picks up right where it left off.
+Two heroes which allow you to choose your play-style.
+They added weekly challenges, which get you to play maps in order to earn extra skulls.
+You can refund your skulls without any penalties as many times as you want.

Cons:
-Orcs Must Die! 2 seems to focus too much on grinding. (in order to beat the Campaign on War Mage you essentially need to play Endless mode to get skulls)
-The guardian limit is still incredibly low.
-There are no levels that corridor enemies so you can just build one long defensive run and have fun with the game.

reviewText:
I'll start off with saying this is a very hard review for me to write. I'm still not entirely sure whether I like OMD!2 or not.

I played through the base OMD!2 campaign with Kataztrophik. Playing games with others always makes for a better experience for me.

Unfortunately I found myself getting bored on more than one occasion. The maps all looked pretty much the same, the variance in enemies is limited, and I found the traps to be uninspired and mostly useless.

I'm a huge fun of TD games. They can be repetitive. The strategy in a TD game comes from playing towers/traps/units in best places, and finding a balance between upgrading and placing new units. Then there's the diversity. Do I need to deal with fast enemies? Maybe they're cloaked? Those ones are flying. Wait! There's a group that are resistant to a certain damage type! Oh no here comes the boss!!!

OMD!2 has none of this. You place a trap and that's it. You can sell it in build phases, but there's no upgrading as the level goes on. Therefore the only option is to spam defences everywhere with your spare cash.

The enemies in OMD!2 are very limited. It has some flyers, some high health hard hitting Ogres, some exploding Kobolds, some fast little buggers, Trolls that regenerate health and then the general mob. Even so they all seem pretty much the same.

The game just spams you with more and more mobs as the level progresses. You counter it by spamming more and more traps. There's no real strategy. Sure the traps filter out some of the bad guys, but you'll be doing most of the killing with your weapons.

This is where the game shines. The action gameplay in combat is pretty good. It's fluid and the weapons are fun to use. However, whilst this is certainly fun it offers nothing ground-breaking or unique. With the lack of variance of the enemy one faces it can also get pretty boring fast.

The biggest thing the game seems to lack for me, is bosses. There should be an epic fight against a might orc, the likes of which has never been seen before! There should be a dragon! A dragon would fit into the games style nicely, and there's no reason why there isn't one.

Overall OMD!2 is a mildly fun action game, with underwhelming TD elements. It's worth playing through the game with a friend, but there are better options available.

Bottom line: Good in short stints with a buddy.

reviewText:
Just as great as the first game. If you've enjoyed Orcs Must Die, you should definitely pick this one up too.

Most of the gameplay is very much similar. You still have a plethora of traps to use, and lots of orcs in each stage. There are fewer overall stages in the main campaign than there were in the first game, but the game offers some new stuff to make up for it. It now has 2 playable characters. Their starting weapons and starting traps are different. Like for example the Apprentice uses a blunderbuss as the main weapon, whereas the sorceress uses a sceptre to shoot small projectiles from. The presence of two playable characters also means the game can be played in co-op.

In addition to this, some stages also have an endless mode, where you can keep fighting hordes of orcs till you lose all the rift points, and the game also lets you play some of the classic stages from the first game.

The upgrade mechanic has been improved from the first game. Though the simplicity of it in the first game was nice, it's also great to have a bigger variety of upgrades that this game offers. Now each trap has more than 1 upgrade, and in addition to upgrading your existing traps, you can also buy new traps, weapons, and trinkets for all sorts of benefits, depending on how you prefer to play. Now this also means that it's easier to earn skulls, which are used as upgrade points. You can now gain them in more ways. In the first game you could only get them as a rating for each mission, but now you can also get them as bonuses and random drops, and as rewards for surviving a certain amount of waves in the endless stages.

Just as with new traps, you also meet some new enemies. We now have some earth elementals which split into two smaller units upon death, some tall, lanky trolls which can take a lot of punishment, and even the regular grunts now have light, medium, and heavy armour varieties.

There are only a couple of minor things I didn't like. The first one is that I was unable to find an easy way to switch between characters when in the campaign menu. I first played through the whole campaign as the Apprentice, and when I wanted to try out the Sorceress, I couldn't simply pick a stage I've beaten already and to do it with her. Instead I had to create a new character profile with no upgrades or unlocks and to start the campaign all over from the start, which isn't all that great.

Another thing I didn't like was how the barricades have become virtually useless now. It's possible that maybe I was just unlucky, but on many occasions I noticed that the orcs now seem to prefer to rather smash their way through the barricades rather take an alternate path, even if the alternate path is within their vision. The only time this didn't happen was when I played the classic levels from the first game.

In conclusion, this is a great 3rd person tower defence game and lives up to the quality of the first one. If you've enjoyed the first one, get this one too. If you've enjoyed this one, get the first one too.

reviewText:
After a long session of Call of Duty I can honestly say I couldn't be happier my friend suggested 'Orcs Must Die! 2' when I asked for a good tower defense game. OMD!2 will honestly be considered one of my favourite games of all time despite only having it for 1 month... it's incredibly fun, addictive and rewarding all at the same time.

The story mode was entertaining due to the variety of strategies you could employ to complete them and the fact that each level can be completed at a different success rate. Beyond this there is an unlockable 'nightmare' mode which adds another layer of strategy to the game as well as making the game more addictive. However the story mode lacked any real in-depth storyline, there were only 2 cut-scenes that I can remember and each were short.

Beyond story mode you could play endless which was interesting due to the more advanced enemies, it could however be deemed a touch repetitive or tedious. I didn't see it this way as it was always rewarded. There are many acheivements to obtain and none of them felt grindy, completing the story mode got you most of them and the others introduced you to other dimensions of the game such as combo'ing (however you will have to pay for DLC to get 100% completion).

Overall I would say the game is definitely worth a purchase at it's cheap price due to it including Steam trading cards / achievements and being thoroughly enjoyable.

reviewText: As excited as I were to get my hands on this game, at the beginning I was nothing less than disappointed. Not sure why either. It just didn't feel like a successful sequel to Orcs Must Die. I left the game untouched for a few months and returned to it, and boy am I glad I did. Not only was I able to rekindle my love with the series, but also couldn't stop playing. The story follows the main protagonist from the first game, and the old nemesis turned good, Sorcerer. Without ruining the story too much, the orcs discover a new way of entering the magical world and destroying civilization. The war mage and sorcerer soon discover pockets of energy emerging at various spots with hundreds of orcs flooding in, and so begins the journey of orc killing.\n\nThe campaign is broken down into two chapters and can be approached on apprentice (easy) and war mage (medium) in solo or cooperative play. Players can unlock harder difficulty by completing war mage difficulty. The goal of each stage is to stop orcs from entering the rift's' using a large assortment of weapons, traps, guardians, spells and trinkets. No complaints in terms of gameplay and AI. Had no problems or hiccups with running the game. Soundtrack just as outstanding as the first. One of the major improvement or sequel demands on the RE forums from the previous title was the inclusion of multiplayer and I'm glad they've taken that into account and applied it to the game as it adds a whole new layer of strategical approach. The war mage possess weapons, traps and trinkets not accessible by the sorcerer - vice versa. Allowing for a greater diversity of strategies to be implemented. The only key downfall of the multiplayer is that you need a Steam buddy with a copy of the game. Alternatively you're stuck with just the single player offering's, although it does not differ from the multiplayer portion. Robot Entertainment has done an excellent job in identifying and amending the shortcomings of the first title. Although the multiplayer aspect leaves little to desire, the current offerings are more than satisfying and the overall package is much bigger than its predecessor.

Orcs Must Die! 2 is a mix of tower defense and third person action. You have to defend your base(s), called rifts in this game, against a horde of Orcs. To do that you build traps and shoot at your enemies with weapons.

The game feels very polished, the graphics have a nice cartoon look, the ragdolls and animations are nice. There is a large variety of traps, weapons and trinkets (artifacts that give special abilities) and all of them can be upgraded. You can build traps wherever you want, which allows for an endless amount of different tactics. The action part isn't about quick reflexes and aiming skills either, it's more part of the tactic you use. Will you defend only a part of the level with traps and try to hold back the hordes in the other part yourself? Or will you put less traps throughout the whole level and kill any enemies that may come through, wherever that may be? What weapon will you use? Use traps to kill the larger enemies and have a weapon that is good for crowd control? Or the other way around? Not kill enemies at all and slow them down instead so your traps can do their dirty work? Lots of possibilities there.

But not everything about the game is great unfortunately. The multiplayer can only be played with (Steam) friends, so no playing with random people like in other games.

The biggest flaw in my opinion are the difficulty levels though. There are three difficulty levels, easy (called Apprentice), normal (called War Mage) and hard (called Nightmare). Easy is not worth playing for anyone who played tower defense games before. Normal can be challenging at times (especially if you want to get the highest rating), but once you've upgraded a good amount of your equipment it's not that hard anymore. After you have completed the game in normal mode you unlock hard mode.

And that's where the problem is. Hard mode could be a real challenge and a lot of fun. More enemies, harder enemies, more madness. But unfortunately they decided to remove the planning phase between waves on that difficulty level. Sure, the game becomes even harder that way. But is that what tower defense games should be about? I want to plan where I put my traps, I want to use a nice tactic. This is not possible in hard mode. After the initial planning phase (where you naturally can only spend the money you start with, which isn't much) you run around like a mad man trying to kill enemies while placing traps and trying to stay alive. No time for thinking, no time to analyze where your defenses aren't strong enough or what you could improve. It's also (more or less, you actually have 3 seconds between waves for it) impossible to sell/replace traps. The game turns from a game that is about tactics and careful planning with a bit of action thrown into the mix into a mad hack and slash action game with a tiny amount of tactics only on that difficulty level. That's a shame and makes the hard difficulty not worth playing in my opinion.

But overall I can still recommend the game, especially since it's cheap and the Complete Edition offers a lot of content that is fun to play at least on normal difficulty.

Orcs Must Die! 2 is a mix of tower defense and third person action. You have to defend your base(s), called rifts in this game, against a horde of Orcs. To do that you build traps and shoot at your enemies with weapons.

The game feels very polished, the graphics have a nice cartoon look, the ragdolls and animations are nice. There is a large variety of traps, weapons and trinkets (artifacts that give special abilities) and all of them can be upgraded. You can build traps wherever you want, which allows for an endless amount of different tactics. The action part isn't about quick reflexes and aiming skills either, it's more part of the tactic you use. Will you defend only a part of the level with traps and try to hold back the hordes in the other part yourself? Or will you put less traps throughout the whole level and kill any enemies that may come through, wherever that may be? What weapon will you use? Use traps to kill the larger enemies and have a weapon that is good for crowd control? Or the other way around? Not kill enemies at all and slow them down instead so your traps can do their dirty work? Lots of possibilities there.

But not everything about the game is great unfortunately. The multiplayer can only be played with (Steam) friends, so no playing with random people like in other games.

The biggest flaw in my opinion are the difficulty levels though. There are three difficulty levels, easy (called Apprentice), normal (called War Mage) and hard (called Nightmare). Easy is not worth playing for anyone who played tower defense games before. Normal can be challenging at times (especially if you want to get the highest rating), but once you've upgraded a good amount of your equipment it's not that hard anymore. After you have completed the game in normal mode you unlock hard mode.

And that's where the problem is. Hard mode could be a real challenge and a lot of fun. More enemies, harder enemies, more madness. But unfortunately they decided to remove the planning phase between waves on that difficulty level. Sure, the game becomes even harder that way. But is that what tower defense games should be about? I want to plan where I put my traps, I want to use a nice tactic. This is not possible in hard mode. After the initial planning phase (where you naturally can only spend the money you start with, which isn't much) you run around like a mad man trying to kill enemies while placing traps and trying to stay alive. No time for thinking, no time to analyze where your defenses aren't strong enough or what you could improve. It's also (more or less, you actually have 3 seconds between waves for it) impossible to sell/replace traps. The game turns from a game that is about tactics and careful planning with a bit of action thrown into the mix into a mad hack and slash action game with a tiny amount of tactics only on that difficulty level. That's a shame and makes the hard difficulty not worth playing in my opinion.

But overall I can still recommend the game, especially since it's cheap and the Complete Edition offers a lot of content that is fun to play at least on normal difficulty.

I suppose how much someone might enjoy OMD2 really depends on if they have a co-op partner.  This game was designed with the idea that you'd be playing co-op.  That doesn't mean you can't play it single player (and the game gives you more inventory slots for traps, weapons and trinkets if you do), but it's a lonely experience.  Even the campaign assumes you'll play co-op, as both characters -- the War Mage and the Sorceress -- converse during the game.

That said, if you do have a co-op partner (my wife is mine), then this game is an absolutel blast!  OMD2 successfully mixes strategy (tower defense), action and some wacky humor, so the game never gets dull or takes itself too seriously.

How you play depends on you.  You could rely more on traps or weapons or even trinkets, although the latter do more to augment gameplay than anything else.  Some weapons and traps are better than others on some maps, so you have to be able to adapt to your surroundings.

If you own the original OMD you get ten maps from the original game to play in OMD2.  Although this is a cool idea, thanking those who've supported the developer, some of the levels aren't new to OMD2 and others don't work extremely well with some of the newer traps.

The newest addition to OMD2 is the toolkit, which lets you create or edit weapons, traps and trinkets.  You can also download items other people have made from the Steam Workshop.

Bottom line:  If you see OMD2 on sale, grab it!  Even at it's normal price, it's still a good deal.  I'd also recommend checking out the developer's website (Robot Entertainment) as they sometimes have deals themselves, which is where my wife and I got our discounted copies.  Don't worry, you get a Steam key.

Orcs Must Die! makes it's return & has some new tricks up it's sleeve.  The hero from the first adventure has to team up with an old enemy for an uneasy truce to fight back the endless horde of enemies.

The game now has co-op mode where the original lacked multiplayer of any kind. This yields some new pros & new cons. The plus side is that the game is much more fun being able to play with a friend, but that's about where the multiplayer perks end. OMD2 is designed mainly for two people to play at once & with the lack of a server browser, game lobby or matchmaking system of any kind, the only way to get people to join you is through friend invites. For somebody who has very few friends that actually plays the game, it's unlikely that they'll be able to get somebody to game with & therefore be able to progress through the game.

The traps & weapons have been hugely overhauled with a good number of additional traps & weapons being added. Trinkets have also been added in the sequel making things more interesting. Equipment can still be gained by playing through the storyline, but a large number of your equipment must be purchased using skulls gained through the game. OMD2 also allows for a wider range of upgrades to your equipment, so you get a choice what bonuses you would like your traps, weapons & trinkets to have & how powerful they are.

Orcs Must Die! 2 at first glance seems like a classical tower defense. You lay traps and have to survive waves of monsters in increasing strength and size. So what makes this game better than other tower defense you may ask.
Firstly, the seamless graphics along with the interesting ability of playing an active and very important role in the defense is major to its sucess. You play as your character and you have to personally mow down the monsters where your traps fail.
Secondly, the monsters require different ways to kill them, a koboldd sprinter is a small and fast unit with not a lot of hitpoints that can bypass most basic traps quite quickly and so need to be coupled either with some well placed shots to the head or another trap to slow the kobold to stop it from passing, whereas a heavy orc warrior would simply require a lot of traps or armor-piercing traps or shots to kill it. This necessity to vary trap combinations and styles plays a major role to the enjoyability of the game.
Thirdly, there are a plethora of traps and weapons to choose from, each providing a unique play style and experience. Thus you can customise your character either too a mean, lean killing machine or you can upgrade your traps say and lay down so nasty little traps in choke points that obliterate the enemy.
Fourthly, the game is not easy. For people who are not very good at tower defense games playing on anything but apprentice level can be a challenge, this skill level requirement or at least a certain level of understanding of the game is necessary as the game is challenging and keeps you on your toes, especially at later stages in the story or in nightmare or endless mode.
Lastly, the aspect of the game that makes it stand out so much from other games is the great co-op aspect. Can you name another tower defense that looks good, plays great, constantly challenges you to play at your best and allows for so many customizations? I think not. So, unless you have found a better tower defense game I highly recommend this game to whoever is looking for a challenging fun and funny game.

I suppose how much someone might enjoy OMD2 really depends on if they have a co-op partner.  This game was designed with the idea that you'd be playing co-op.  That doesn't mean you can't play it single player (and the game gives you more inventory slots for traps, weapons and trinkets if you do), but it's a lonely experience.  Even the campaign assumes you'll play co-op, as both characters -- the War Mage and the Sorceress -- converse during the game.

That said, if you do have a co-op partner (my wife is mine), then this game is an absolutel blast!  OMD2 successfully mixes strategy (tower defense), action and some wacky humor, so the game never gets dull or takes itself too seriously.

How you play depends on you.  You could rely more on traps or weapons or even trinkets, although the latter do more to augment gameplay than anything else.  Some weapons and traps are better than others on some maps, so you have to be able to adapt to your surroundings.

If you own the original OMD you get ten maps from the original game to play in OMD2.  Although this is a cool idea, thanking those who've supported the developer, some of the levels aren't new to OMD2 and others don't work extremely well with some of the newer traps.

The newest addition to OMD2 is the toolkit, which lets you create or edit weapons, traps and trinkets.  You can also download items other people have made from the Steam Workshop.

Bottom line:  If you see OMD2 on sale, grab it!  Even at it's normal price, it's still a good deal.  I'd also recommend checking out the developer's website (Robot Entertainment) as they sometimes have deals themselves, which is where my wife and I got our discounted copies.  Don't worry, you get a Steam key.

Orcs Must Die 2 continues right where 1 left off. The much-awaited multiplayer experience is here, but this review will be from a single-player standpoint.

To start with, you get to pick between the Warmage and the Sorceress. Both have their strengths and weaknesses, but the Warmage simply feels easier to play with due to his superior health, superior tar trap, and arguably superior weapon. The Sorceress is better for charming single, large targets though, and her acid trap does more damage than the Warmage's Arrow Trap.

Gameplay is more or less the same. If you played OMD1, this will all be familiar. The Elementalist girls are gone, which is a shame. This change means that you have less options to adjust to your enemies in the middle of a level. Fortunately any upgrades you purchased prior to battle can be reset at no cost. Autoballistae are now considered guardians, which means you can no longer spam them. I was sad about that as well.

Amazingly they made the Gnolls more irritating. They seem to have more HP, run faster (both probably untrue, but it feels like it), and can now slow you upon hitting you, making escape impossible. A whole pack of them, especially in Endless mode (see below), will ruin your day.

I'm rather disappointed that the campaign is so short. The first game took maybe 15-20 hours to complete, and had a good progression. OMD2 instead took me a mere 10 hours on normal difficulty. Granted, I already knew the basics of the game, but this was far shorter than I expected. DLC's extend the game's length a bit, but they contain no story segments, and thus you are basically playing for skulls (the game's peristent currency) and variety. Note that you'll have to play through Campaign again with another character if you want stuff unlocked on both characters.

Endless mode is interesting. Waves come indefinitely and keep getting tougher until you can no longer handle it, much like Survival mode in other types of games. This mode by far is the biggest time-sink, though you are rewarded with plenty of skulls to compensate.

If you like the first game and want a way to play it with friends, then OMD2 is the way to go. Overall it's an acceptable game. I still recommend the first game though.

Orcs Must Die! 2 at first glance seems like a classical tower defense. You lay traps and have to survive waves of monsters in increasing strength and size. So what makes this game better than other tower defense you may ask.
Firstly, the seamless graphics along with the interesting ability of playing an active and very important role in the defense is major to its sucess. You play as your character and you have to personally mow down the monsters where your traps fail.
Secondly, the monsters require different ways to kill them, a koboldd sprinter is a small and fast unit with not a lot of hitpoints that can bypass most basic traps quite quickly and so need to be coupled either with some well placed shots to the head or another trap to slow the kobold to stop it from passing, whereas a heavy orc warrior would simply require a lot of traps or armor-piercing traps or shots to kill it. This necessity to vary trap combinations and styles plays a major role to the enjoyability of the game.
Thirdly, there are a plethora of traps and weapons to choose from, each providing a unique play style and experience. Thus you can customise your character either too a mean, lean killing machine or you can upgrade your traps say and lay down so nasty little traps in choke points that obliterate the enemy.
Fourthly, the game is not easy. For people who are not very good at tower defense games playing on anything but apprentice level can be a challenge, this skill level requirement or at least a certain level of understanding of the game is necessary as the game is challenging and keeps you on your toes, especially at later stages in the story or in nightmare or endless mode.
Lastly, the aspect of the game that makes it stand out so much from other games is the great co-op aspect. Can you name another tower defense that looks good, plays great, constantly challenges you to play at your best and allows for so many customizations? I think not. So, unless you have found a better tower defense game I highly recommend this game to whoever is looking for a challenging fun and funny game.

Orcs Must Die 2 is the sequel to Orcs Must Die (obviously) and as lazy as it sounds I would recommend reading my review of that because this game is essentially the same again. Not that that's a bad thing! The formula works, hell in this one they even improved a few things.
This time you can choose between 2 characters to play as, the apprentice or the antagonist from the previous game. Each of the characters has their strengths and weaknesses, the apprentice carries on as he did before but now gives you the choice of crossbow, blunderbuss. The crossbow being the same as the last game and the blunderbuss causing far more damage but having a much longer reload time. The sorceress has less health than the apprentice but more mana and she can control a Orc and make him fight the others for a short period. As well as that some of the starting traps are different depending on which you choose as well as a few unlockables later.
Speaking of traps there are some new ones, all of which are entertaining to see unfold, the levels also sometimes have environmental traps built in which you can take advantage of.
This time there are far more unlockables to collect, costumes that change your abilities, rings and trinkets to enhance the way you play and of course the upgrades.

Like the first game it's repetitive as hell, but what do you expect? And also like the first it's difficulty seems to ramp up out of nowhere.

I recommend this game to those who have either played the first and want more of the same. If your new to the series... Well start here. It's a better game really, since it's the first one plus extras.
I'd say Â£11.99 is a little steep though considering the first is essentially the same minus a few parts. See if you can find it a bit cheaper or on a sale. Anything below Â£10 is a bargain really.

At the time of this posting, Orcs Must Die 2 is 90% off; That's less than $2!

Orcs Must Die 2 is a tower defence game that puts equal emphasis on the player and the traps he/she places, as in one cannot win without the other on the harder difficulties. You can choose the 4-8 traps, weapons, and utilities you use at the beginning of each round, and upgrade them too. The upgrade system allows you to choose one of two unique stat buffs / extra abilities, and gives an additional aspect to modify your items each round. There is a lot of clicking involved for some personal items (especially the sorceress's Staff of Domination). Co-op is also an aspect which, in my opinion, enhances the experience to a degree; However, the game can be completed entirely alone.

The OST is most noticable during the beginning of the waves, and the last wave, where it conveys the chaos taking place when the late-game waves start throwing hundreds of orcs, imps, golems and trolls at you. Orcs Must Die 2 definately has some charm to it's presentation.

Overall, I think it's a no brainer to pick it up on sale, as it provided me with a good 20 or so hours of fun (though I did not complete all DLC maps)

Quick Summary: Orcs Must Die 2 is the co-op follow-up to the original game and while there are changes in maps and some of the traps, the core gameplay is the same. This is a good thing because the first Orcs Must Die is awesome, and only lacked the ability to play with your friends.

Spoilers Ahead
If youâve played the first Orcs Must Die recently you will remember that at the end, the war mage (you) closed the rifts into the orc world and trapped the evil sorceress on the other side with her minions. Closing the rifts had the side effect of making magic unusable, so the power she had over the orcs is gone, and now they want her dead. In this sequel, one last rift is opened by an old wise wizard (presumed dead in the first game) and the sorceress has escaped being chased by her former orcs. Itâs team up time, and the war mage must work with the sorceress to stop the hordes of orcs from breaking through the rift into the human world.

This time around you can choose which character to play the game as: war mage or sorceress. Mostly theyâre the same but each has a couple of traps unique to them.  For example the war mage has the tar trap (one of the best floor traps) and the sorceress has the acid spray wall trap (decent against heavy enemies). Consensus seems to be that war mage is better overall. I played the sorceress and had fun with the polymorph ring against the super heavy enemies.

Just like the first Orcs Must Die, the game is broken up into a series of independent map levels, and every level you start from scratch setting up traps and barricades to kill all the orcs before they reach the rift (or rifts). Itâs a hybrid tower defense/third person shooter, so youâre in the thick of the action, blasting enemies along with your traps, or mopping up the ones who manage to break past. Every level you beat gives you âskullsâ which are currency to buy upgrades for traps or unlock new spells/traps. Unlike the first game, you can replay levels over and over to farm skulls and eventually buy every upgrade.

Pros:
+Co-op campaign! You can play every level with a friend. This along with the skull farming adds a lot of replayability to the campaign.
+Pretty much everything good in the first game is still there, including maps for the first game. You can play the âclassic levelsâ with the new traps and sorceress character.


Cons:
-The âendless modeâ gets buggy as you get to higher levels. Maybe itâs my computer but it really started to lag around wave 35. It actually crashed for me a couple times.

Overall, if you liked Orcs Must Die 1, you should like part 2. Theyâre basically the same game with added improvements, options, and levels for the sequel.

The goal of the game is to stop the baddies (mostly orcs, thus the game's name) from reaching the ending points once they spawn at starting points.

Easy enough right?  Wrong =p plenty of enemy types, and lot and lots of them.  And how you go about attacking them is totally up to you and the tools you choose to get the job done.

There are various different traps, helpers (guardians), trinkets (like armor pieces), and weapons you can equip and upgrade via skulls you earn from how you do on each lvl you play through, fun process and makes it have something to work towards ;) ; rewarding to say the least.

Even at full price I'd can whole heartedly recommend this game, the dlc on other hand I'm not totally sure of yet, b/c most of the dlc was included in the pack I bought, so hard for me to judge the bang for buck on the dlc.

Opening caveat:  I am not traditionally a person that plays Tower Defense games.  This is in fact my first one.

While you can play all the missions single player...the game is at its best (IMO) when played with a friend.  Many a map benefits heavily from having a second mind on hand to help combat the games challenges, and with co-op your individual action bar is halved so it emphasizes working and planning together.

The missions also reward player skill with the main currency of the game, skulls.  Doing things like beating a mission within a certain time limit...not letting anyone through your defenses...and even hidden" bonuses like not using mana or not taking damage all reward you with additional skulls after the level.
